p: Phylogenetic inference methods are based on comparisons of sequence differences among contemporaneous viral isolates. In heterochronous sampling, the sequences obtained from viruses isolated at different times [ 13, 14, 15, 16] provide calibration points for phylogenetic comparisons. Specimens from more distant times [ 13] occasionally yield additional sequences that can be used to calibrate phylogenies [ 17, 18, 19]. Similarly, paleo-sequences, or endogenous viral elements (EVEs) [ 20], can also be used in the calibration of trees. The fact that phylogenetic trees, for numerous viral taxa, resemble, in topology and branch lengths, the trees constructed for their predominant hosts, argues for the co-divergence of nucleotide sequences of the host and virus during the evolution of host lineages [ 21], and provides a further calibration approach.
